respStmt.note: Original description encoded for The Production and Use of English Manuscripts: 1060 to 1220.
Revisions to the markup of the original description to conform to Bodleian ODD.

licence.p: Both the original description for The Production and Use of English Manuscripts: 1060 to 1220 and any modifications to the encoding made here are licenced CC BY-NC 3.0.

sourceDesc.p: The original encoded description for The Production and Use of English Manuscripts: 1060 to 1220 is at: https://stacks.stanford.edu/file/druid:mt606ky7205/EM.Ox.Juni.121.xml (access via https://purl.stanford.edu/mt606ky7205)

msDesc.head: Ecclesiastical Institutes, Homilies; England (Worcester), s. xi 2, glossed s. xiii 1

msContents.summary: A book for episcopal use, including canonical, penitential, and homiletic texts, many associated with Archbishop Wulfstan (d. 1023) and his commonplace book tradition (see Bateson 1895; Sauer 2000). The manuscript was produced in Worcester a generation or so after Archbishop Wulfstan's death, during the episcopate of St Wulfstan (1062–95), and compiled c. 1060–72, with Hatton 113 and Hatton 114 (Franzen 1998, p. 55–56). Glosses added by the so-called Tremulous Hand of Worcester in the thirteenth century.

msItem.note: A table of contents (fols. 5–8) preceded by canon law extracts (fols. 1v-4v), precedes five numbered sections: (1) I-XLIII (fols 9r-69v); (2) I-XV (fols 69v-74r); (3) I-XXX (fols 74r-80v); (4) I-XVI (fols 80v-84v); (5) I-XXX (fols 84v-110v). The last four sections (2)-(5) are referred to as Books 1–4; the first three books (2)-(4) (fols. 69v-84v) correspond to the first three books of the 'Penitential of Pseudo-Egbert', while the fourth is miscellaneous. The endleaves (fols. iii recto - vi recto) contain additions of the 13th century. The numbering of items follows Ker.
Additions on the endleaves, thirteenth century
fol. iii r: nine words in four columns; fol. iii v: two word pairs (otherwise blank) All in the Tremulous Hand. (For later notes on fols. ii verso and iii recto see Provenance).
One word pair in the Tremulous Hand (pencil)

msItem.incipit: vi r/1 -vi r/1 Robertus rex francorum victime pascali ...
msItem.explicit: vi r/13-vi r/14 Robertus eboracensis: exultemus i hac die festiva; Quidam canonicus toruacensis.ʹ historiam de trinitate.
msItem.note: A list of writers of hymns, and hymns ascribed to them. Reproduced in Crawford 1928, p. 5.

msItem.incipit: vi r/15 : Ic ileue on enne god fæder almihti

msItem.note: In top margin, s. xiii, 'recti diligunt te suete lefdi seinte marie'; immediately below it, in the Tremulous Hand, a string of Latin synonyms.
Fols. vi verso, vii recto-verso blank.
Table of contents, preceded by canon law extracts

msItem.incipit:
Benedicamus uos regnanti desuper gratias domino
Deo per secula pueri reddite gratias.

This page is blank apart from two neumed lines, and writ ðus above this.

2v/11 : Quod nulli liceat duobus episcop atibus praesidere.

Hand 3; after 1070; Whitelock et al. (1981), II.575–6.

msItem.incipit: 3r/11 Haec est pęnitentie institutio

msItem.explicit:
4v/17–18x Supplan
tationes uero ęcclesiarum omnibus modis interdicimus . FINIT.

msItem.incipit: 5r/3 I Be heofonlicum cynincge
msItem.explicit: 8r/13 Be preoste sinoðe
msItem.note: Fol. 7v: scribe stops using two columns and just writes contents out in one column. Fol. 8v is blank.

msItem.author: Wulfstan
msItem.title: Institutes of Polity
msItem.note: Arts. 1–4, 6–10, 13–14 comprise the revised version (II Polity). Here presented in a sequence of chapters numbered I-XLIII, incorporating additional texts, arts. 5, 11, 12, 15–22.

msItem.title: II Polity, 1–3
msItem.incipit:
9r/2–4 IN NOMINI DOMINI
An is ece cyning ƿealdend and ƿyrhta ealra gesceafta.
msItem.explicit: 9r/6–7 Him symble sy lof and ƿuldor and ece ƿyrðmynt á to ƿorulde. Amen.

msItem.title: II Polity, 4–22
msItem.incipit: 9r/9–12 CHRISTENUM CYNINGE gebyreð on cristenre þeode þæt he sy ealsƿa hit riht is folces frófer and rihtƿis hyrde ofer cristene heorde.
msItem.explicit: 10r/20–22 Ac se byð gesælig þe godcunde lare oftost gehyreð and geornlicast healdeþ.

msItem.title: II Polity, 23–30
msItem.incipit:
10r/23 EAHTA SǷERAS SYNDON
þe rihtlicne cynedom trumlice upƿegað
msItem.explicit: 10v/14–16 ˥ seofoðe, þæt he be freondan and be fremdan fadige gelice on rihtlican dome.

msItem.title: II Polity, 31–40
msItem.incipit:
10v/17–19 ÆLC RIHT CYNESTOL STENT
on þrym stapelum þe fullice ariht stent
on þrym stapelum · þe fullice a riht stent
áris.
msItem.explicit: 11r/17–19 Ac dó man sƿa hit þearf is alecge man únriht and rære up Godes riht þæt mæg to þearfe for Gode and for ƿorulde. Amen .

msItem.title: II Polity, 41–57
msItem.incipit:
11r/21–12r/2 CYNINGAN AND BISCEOPAN.
eorlan ˥ heretogan gerefan and deman
larƿitan and lahƿitan gedafenað mid rihte
for Gode and for ƿorulde
þ æt hi ánræde ƿeorðan and Godes riht lufian.
msItem.explicit:
12r/21–12v/2 Ic ƿat sƿyðe georne me sylfne forƿorhtne
ƿordes and dæde ealles to sƿyðe ne dear
þeah for forsƿygian mid ealle
Godes ege fela þara þinga þe dereð þisse þeode.

msItem.title: II Polity, 58–76
msItem.incipit:
12v/4–7 BISCEOPAS SCULAN BOCVM
˥ gebedum fyligean ˥ dæges ˥ nihtes oft ˥ gelome clypian to Criste ˥ for eall cristen
folc þingian georne.
msItem.explicit:
13v/3–6 Nu lære ƿe eac georne
manna gehƿylcne þ æt he Godes larum ˥ his
lagum fylgie þonne geearnað he him ece
myrhðe.

msItem.author: Wulfstan
msItem.title: Concerning Episcopal Duties (Episcopus)
msItem.incipit:
13v/7–9 BISCEOPE GEBYREÐ ÆLC
rihting ge on godcundan þingan ge on
ƿoruldcundan.
msItem.explicit:
15r/1–3 Þ y ƿe agan þearfe þæt ƿe ðam beorgan þe us
scylan hyran þonne gebide ƿe þe mare
gebeorh æt Godes agenum dome.

msItem.title: II Polity, 77–81
msItem.incipit:
15r/4–7 BISCEOPES DÆGǷEORC ÐÆT
bið mid rihte his gebedu ærest ˥ ðonne
his boc ƿeorc · ˥ ræding oððon rihting lar oððon leornung
msItem.explicit:
15r/14–16 ˥ eac him gerisð ƿel þæt he on gemote
oft ˥ gelome godcunde lare dæle þam
folce þe he þonne mid sy.

msItem.title: II Polity, 82–84
msItem.incipit:
15r/17–20 A GERIST. BISCEOPUM. ǷISDOM
˥ ƿærscype ˥ þæt þa habban ƿeorðlice
ƿisan þa þa heom fylian ˥ þæt hy sundor
cræfta sumne eac cunnen .
msItem.explicit: 15v/1–3 Ac ƿisdom ˥ ƿærscipe gedafeniað heora hade ˥ gedrihþa gerisaþ þam ðe heom fyliað.

msItem.title: Bisceopes dægweorc
msItem.incipit: 15v/5 Deus in adiutorium meum intende. ter.
msItem.explicit:
Bisceopum gebyreð þæt hi mid geþylde geþo
lian þæt hi sylfe begetan ne magan oð þæt
hit þa, cyncge gecyþed ƿeorðe ˥ bete he
syððan Godes abylhþe þær bisceop
ne mæge gif he Godes ƿillan rihte ƿylle
ƿyrcean ˥ his agene cynescype rihtlice
aræran.

msItem.title: II Polity, 85–93
msItem.incipit:
17r/11–14 EORLAS AND HERETOGAN.
˥ ðas ƿoruld deman. and eac sƿa gere
fan agan nydþearfe þaet hi riht lufian
for Gode ˥ for ƿorulde.
msItem.explicit:
17v/9–13 Ac dó freonda
gehyƿylc eallsƿa hit þearf is ƿarnige hine
georne ˥ beorge him sylfum þæt he God ne á
belge ealles to sƿyðe ac cƿeme his drihtne
mid rihtlicre dæde.

msItem.title: II Polity, 94–101
msItem.incipit:
17v/14–16 RIHT IS ÐÆT GEREFAN GE
eornlice tylian ˥ symle heora hla
fordan strynan mid rihte.
msItem.explicit:
18r/14–17 ˥ ƿa þæs gestreones þam þe his mæst hafaþ
on unriht gestryned butan he gesƿice
˥ ðe deoppor gebete for Gode ˥ for ƿor
ulde.
msItem.note: Erasure in word division on fol. 18r

msItem.title: II Polity, 170–2
msItem.incipit:
18r/18–21 RIHT IS ÞÆT ABBODAS ˥ HVRV
abbadissan fæste on mynstrum sing
allice ƿunian ˥ georne heora heorda
symle beguman ˥ áá heom ƿel bysenian
˥ rihtlice bodian
msItem.explicit:
18v/2–3 sƿa gebyreð abbo
dan ˥ munuchades mannum.

msItem.title: II Polity, 173–84
msItem.incipit:
14v/4–7 RIHT IS ÞÆT MUNECAS BEON
dæges ˥ nihtes inƿeardre heortan
á to Gode þencan ˥ geornlice clypian ˥ mid
eallum eadmedum regollice libban.
msItem.explicit:
19r/19–22 Ac ƿe agan néode þæt ƿe hit gebetan sƿa ƿe
geornost magan ˥ ƿeorðan anmode
to gemænelicre þearfe for Gode and for
ƿorulde.

msItem.title: II Polity, 185
msItem.incipit:
19v/1–5 ARIHT IS ÞÆT MYNECENA
mynsterlice macian efne sƿa ƿe cƿædon æror be munecan ˥ ne toƿettan ƿoruldmannum ne ænige sundorcyððe to heom habban ealles to sƿyðe
msItem.explicit: 19v/5–7 ac á regolice libban ˥ hi symle asyndrian fram ƿoruldbysegan sƿa hi geornost magan.

msItem.title: II Polity, 186
msItem.incipit:
19v/9–13 RIHT IS ÐÆT PREOSTAS
˥ efen ƿel nunnan regollice libban ˥ clænnysse healdan be þam þe hi ƿillan on mynstran geƿunian oððon for ƿorulde ƿeorðscypes ƿealdan.
msItem.note: Fol. 19r/23 is blank - there is a tear in the parchment.

msItem.title: II Polity, 198–202
msItem.incipit:
19v/14–15 RIHT IS ÐÆT ǷYDEǷAN. AN
nan bysenan geornlice fylian.
msItem.explicit:
9v/22–3 Sƿa sceall gód
ƿydeƿe hyran hyre drihtne.

msItem.title: On the Servants of God
msItem.incipit:
20r/2–5 LEOFAN MEN IC BIDDE.
geyrað hƿæt ic ƿylle secgan þurh godes
gyfe us eallum to þearfe gecnaƿe se þe
cunne.
msItem.explicit:
20v/11–12 And gyf he elles
do gebete hit georne.

msItem.title: II Polity, 102–44
msItem.incipit:
20v/13–16 SACERDAS SCULAN ON HEORA
scrift scirum ƿislice ˥ ƿærlice lædan
˥ læran þa godcundan heorda þe hi healdan
sculan.
msItem.explicit:
23r/22–23v/3 Nis se man on life þe areccan mæge
ealle þa yrmða þe se gebidan sceall se ðe
on þa ƿitu ealles behreoseð ˥ hit is ealles
þe ƿyrse þe his ænig ende ne cymð næfre
to ƿorulde.
msItem.filiation: Nero A. i ; Tiberius A. iii ; CCCC 201

msItem.title: To Priests
msItem.incipit:
23v/4–7 LA LEOF VNDERSTANDAÐ
eoƿ sylfe ˥ lufiað ˥ ƿeorðiað God ælmih
tigne ofer ealle oðre þinc ˥ healdað his
beboda georne.
msItem.explicit:
24r/18–21 Be mannes geƿrihtum hit man mot secan
æfter canondóme ˥ eac medemian be mihtum
˥ be mæþe ˥ be þam þe man ongit his heortan
hreoƿsunge ˥ his sylfes geornfulnesse.

msItem.title: To Priests
msItem.incipit:
25r/1–4 TÆCAÐ CRISTENUM MANNUM
georne ˥ gelome rihtne geleafan ˥ þæt hi
cunnon heora cristendome ˥ heora
fulluhtes gescead ƿitan.
msItem.explicit:
25v/3–6 God ælmihtig helpe ure ˥ sancta
Maria ˥ gefultumie us eallum þæt ƿe ægðer
ge us sylfe ge þa þe ƿe ƿisian sceolan sƿa
geƿisian motan sƿa sƿa ure ealra þearf sy.

msItem.author: Wulfstan
msItem.title: Canons of Edgar
msItem.incipit:
25v/8–10 RIHT IS ÞÆT PREOSTAS BEON
geornlice gode þeoƿiende ˥ ðeniende
˥ for eall cristen folc ðingiende
msItem.explicit:
31v/8–9 Þonne geleanað him þæt
god ælmihtig sƿa him leofost bið. Amen.
msItem.note:
Fol. 26-small hole at line 6; fol. 26r/13 addition-by main scribe?; fol. 27v/14 and first word of line 15 erasedl; fol. 28v/4-note by Coleman in the margin: Gylden oððe
seolfren
amen (next to: ˥ riht is þæt ælc calic gegote beo).

msItem.title: II Polity, 187–97
msItem.incipit:
31v/11–13 RIHT IS ÐÆT GEHADODE MEN
læƿede ƿisian hu hi heora æƿe rihtlicost
sculon healdan.
msItem.explicit:
32r/11–13 Nagon læƿede men
freolstídum ne fæstentídum þurh hæmed
ðing ƿifes gemanan þe ma þe heahhades men
þæt ðing agan ænigum timan.

msItem.title: II Polity, 145–69
msItem.incipit:
32r/15–18 GEHADEDVM MANNVM
gebyreð ælc clænnes forðam þe hi
sculon eallum oðrum mannum ælce un
clænnesse forbeodan.
msItem.explicit: 34r/1–3 God eoƿ getrymme to eoƿre agenre þearfe ˥ us ealle gehealde sƿa his ƿylla sy. Amen.

msItem.title: Be gehadedum mannum (Duties of Clergy / On Men in Orders, II Polity app. c. 23)
msItem.incipit:
34r/5–9 LEOFAN MEN IN LIBRO VISI
onum is aƿriten hu þa mæssepreostas
˥ ða diaconas þe misleofedan her on ƿorulde
ƿæron on ƿælhreoƿlice geseƿene
sƿa sƿa se encgel gesƿutelode on ðære gesihðe.
msItem.explicit:
35v/12–17 ˥ se þe
heahhád underfo gyf he sy mæssepreost
þonne gemæssige he for his biscop XXX
mæssan ˥ diacon gesinge XXX psaltera
˥ áá heora lifdagas gebiddon þærto
eacan for hine georne.
msItem.note: Glosses from the scribe with the very long ascenders and descenders.

msItem.title: De ecclesiasticis gradibus (II Polity app. c. 24)
msItem.incipit:
35v/19–21 HEAHHADAS SYNDON
to healdenne. mid sƿiðe miclum ƿis
dome ˥ mid ealre clænnesse.
msItem.explicit:
42r/17–18 God us gefylste þæt ƿe moton ealle sƿa don.
Amen.
msItem.filiation: CCCC 190 ; CCCC 201 . Second half also in Napier XLVI
msItem.note: There is a major heading on fol. 40r/15 (beg. NE BEO NAN MAN OÐRES; catalogued by Ker as part of Napier XLVI) but this seems to be a division in one text rather than two since there is no new rubric. Glosses throughout by the Tremulous Hand, who has also noted each of the orders in the margins (as well as other glossing). fol. 39: small hole in parchment.

msItem.title: The Benedictine Office
msItem.rubric:
42r/18 xxu De officiis diurnalium noctur
nalium horarum
msItem.incipit:
42r/20–23 GODCUND ÞEOǷDOM IS GE
sett on cyriclicum þenungum æfter
canoneclican geƿunan to nýdrihte eallum
gehadedum mannum.
msItem.explicit: 55v/20 God ús gefultumige. to ure ðearfe sƿa his ƿylla sy. amen.
msItem.filiation: CCCC 201 contains the prose parts of this exposition with minor variations, and a poem (Gloria) which has been used in the composition of this text. The metrical psalm-verses are almost identical to those in the Paris Psalter.
msItem.note: Fol. 43r (half-sheet) has two small holes in the bottom righthand corner, and on fol. 51v note by Coleman .

msItem.author: Wulfstan
msItem.title: The Christian Faith: A Rule for Canons (Bethurum 10a)
msItem.incipit:
ÆALDLICE LAH
geƿritu.
˥ eac godƿpellice bebodu us lærað ˥ myngiað þæt ƿe eallum mode
˥ eallum mægene ærest God lufian ˥ ƿurðian ˥ syðþan ure nextan lufian ˥ healdan sƿa sƿa us sylfe.
msItem.explicit: þonne geearnað hy lof æt mannum ˥ æt Gode sylfum ece edlean.

msItem.title: II Polity, 203–222
msItem.incipit:
RIHT IS ÐÆT CRISTENE MEN
cristendom georne healdan mid rihte ˥ Cristes cyrican æghƿær geornlice ƿeorþian ˥ ƿerian.
msItem.explicit: ˥ utan ænne cynehlaford holdlice healdan ˥ freonda gehƿylc oðerne healde mid rihtan getryƿðan.

msItem.title: II Polity, 223–34
msItem.incipit:
RIHT IS ÐÆT EALLE CRISTE
ne men heora cristendom rihtlice
healdan ˥ ðam life libban þe heom to gebyrað æfter Godes rihte ˥ æfter ƿoruldgerysenum
msItem.explicit: ˥ beorgan us georne ƿið þone ƿeallendan bryne helleƿites ˥ geearnian us ða mærða ˥ myrhða ðe God hæfð gegearƿod þam ðe his ƿillan on ƿorulde geƿyrcað. Amen.

msItem.author: Wulfstan
msItem.title: Evil Days: God's Threat to Sinning Israel (Bethurum 19)
msItem.incipit:
VTAN SPURIAN
be bocan.
msItem.explicit:
Ðis sýnd þa Godes ƿord þe god sýlf gedihte
˥ moýse befæste ˥ eal hit mæg to býsne
æghƿýlcere ðeode gýme se ðe ƿille god
XXXVIII us gehealde · amen ·
msItem.note:
major heading at fol. 60r/17L EALA LEOFAN MEN BE þylcan bysenan ƿe us magon ƿar
nian.

msItem.title: Confessionale Pseudo-Egberti: Additional sections printed by Spindler [sections a-l]
msItem.rubric:
Her is scrift ˥ an
detnes ægðer tƿegra ge gehadodra. gelæ
ƿedra. þæra þe þæs andgites habbað. ˥ ðæs
ledenes deopnesse ne cunnon.
msItem.incipit:
ÞONNE MAN TO HIS SCRIFTE
gangeð · þonne sceall he mid sƿýðe mý
celum godes ege ˥ eadmodnesse beforan
christum hine aþenian · and hine biddan ƿépen
dre stefne ·

msItem.title: Anonymous Homily
msItem.incipit:
LEOFA MAN ÐE IS MYCEL
þearf þæt ðu þas drihtenlican tíde georne geþence.

msItem.author: Wulfstan
msItem.title: The Christian Faith: Translation of the Pater Noster and of the Creed (Bethurum 7a)
msItem.rubric:
64r/17 xxxuiiii Be ðæs halgan sun
nandæges gebede.
msItem.incipit:
LEOFAN MENN
understandað georne eallsƿa eoƿ mycel
ðearf is.

msItem.title: Handbook for the Use of a Confessor
msItem.rubric:
65v/14 xl Be þæs mæssepreostas ge
sceadƿisnysse.
msItem.incipit:
ÞÆT SCEALL GE
þencan se ðe byð manna saƿla lǽce.

msItem.title: Handbook for the Use of a Confessor
msItem.incipit:
ON ǷISUM SCRIFTE BYÞ
sƿyðe forð ge lang.

msItem.title: Handbook for the Use of a Confessor
msItem.incipit:
SE LÆCA ÐE SCEL
sare ƿunda ƿel gehælan.

msItem.title: Confessionale Pseudo-Egberti: Additional sections printed by Spindler [sections n-x]
msItem.rubric:
67v/17 xliii Be
þeódores gesetnysse hu man sceall fæs
ten alýsan.
msItem.incipit:
ÐEODORVS SE HALGA.
˥ se goda biscop gesetta þas rædinge.

msItem.title: Poenitentiale Pseudo-Egberti
msItem.rubric:
69v/8 i INCIPIT
LIBER primus. cum capitolis atque cum suis sentialis, Þis is ærest se forma capitul ...
msItem.incipit:
HIT GEBYRAÐ ÞÆT SE SA
cerd smeage

msItem.title: Confessionale Pseudo-Egberti
msItem.rubric:
87r/11 ii Iu
dicium de peccatis multis.
msItem.incipit: Seo æreste forlætnes is fyrena fulƿiht.
msItem.note: In Spindler's edition the order of the sections differs.

msItem.title: Poenitentiale Pseudo-Egberti
msItem.incipit:
GYF HYǷLC MAN ǷIFIGE ON HIS
nextan magan
msItem.note: It also occurs on fol. 77v as Book 2, chap. 17

msItem.colophon:
101r/15–18 Me scripsit wulfgeatus scriptor
wigornensis. ora obsecrio pro ipsius neuis
cosmi satorem. Amen. Et qui me scripsit
semper sit felix. AMEN.
msItem.note: Possibly copied from exemplar rather than original to the main scribe, since it follows directly from the previous item.

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Letters: Letter to Wulfsige
msItem.incipit:
Ælfricus humilis frater uenerabili episcopo
wulfsino salutem indigno.
msItem.note: After this item there are possibly some pages missing. This marks a change of plan in the production of the manucript, which seems originally to have been intended with Hatton 113 and Hatton 114 as one large volume.

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Letters: Second Old English Letter for Wulfstan
msItem.rubric:
111r/1 DE SEUNDA [sic] EPISTOLA QUANDO DIUIDIS
CRISMA
msItem.incipit: Eala ge mæssepreostas mine gebroðru.
msItem.explicit: Gefultumige us se hælend to his halgum bebodum se þe leofad mid his leofan fæder ˥ ðam halgan gaste on anre godcundnysse hi þrý án God, æfre rixiende. Amen.
msItem.filiation: CCCC 190 ; Bodley 343 ; Vespasian D. xiv ; Tiberius A. iii

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Letters: Letter to Wulfgeat
msItem.incipit: Esto consentiens aduersario.
msItem.note: This is a homily adapted from Ælfric's Letter to Wulfgeat : it does not contain the first 89 lines in Assman's edition.

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Homilies of Ælfric: Dominica Post Ascensionem Domini
msItem.incipit:
Cum autem uenerit paraclitus quem
ego mittam uobis a patre. Et reliqua .
Se hæland her on life.

msItem.author: Wulfstan
msItem.title: Eschatalogical Homilies: Antichrist
msItem.incipit:
Leofan men understandað sƿyðe georne
þæt ge rihtlice ˥ ƿærlice

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: First Sunday in Advent
msItem.incipit:
Ðíses dæges þéning ˥ þissere tide mærð
sprecað ymbe godes tocyme.

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: Second Sunday in Advent
msItem.incipit: Se godspellere lucas aƿrát on ðisum dægðerlican godspelle.

msItem.title: Anonymous Homilies, Homilies for Specified Occasions, Temporale: Easter Day: De Descensu Christe ad Inferos
msItem.incipit:
Nu ƿe habbað eoƿ gesæd
anfealdlice
msItem.explicit: þurh ealra ƿorulda ƿorod Amen.

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: English Preface [adapted]
msItem.incipit: Menn behofiað godre lare
msItem.filiation: The preface has been adapted as a homily: the same adaptation is found in Hatton 115 .
msItem.note: On fol. 155v, with musical notes: Iste homo ab atholescentia sua partim meruit in firmos curare dedit illi dominus claritatem magnam cecos illuminare et demones effugare.

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Second Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies II]: Assumption of the Virgin
msItem.incipit:
INTRAUIT IESUS IN QUODDAM CASTELLUM . RELIQUA .
Se hælend becom into sumere eaðlican byrig.

msItem.note: Glosses throughout by the Tremulous Hand; some later glosses (e.g. arts. 5, 8).

foliation.p: Foliated. An earlier foliation in Joscelyn's hand starts from 1 on fol. 102 and ends at 59 on fol. 160. ( Franzen 1998, pp. 56, 58)

supportDesc.collation: 1–16 8 ; 3 and 6 in Quires 5 and 6 are half-sheets; 17 10 ; 18–19 8 ; 20 8 wants 8, probably blank. Fol. 161 (the last of Quire 20) is paper. Quire signatures are marked on the left hand side of the bottom margin of the last verso of Quire 2: 'a' (fol. 16v); and on left hand side of the bottom margin of the first recto of Quires 3–14: 'b' (fol. 17r); 'c' (fol. 25r); 'd' (fol. 33r); 'e' (fol. 41r); 'f' (fol. 49r); 'g' (fol. 57r); 'h' (fol. 64r); 'i' (fol. 72r); 'k' (fol. 80r); 'l' (fol. 88r); 'm' (fol. 96r); 'n' (fol. 104r). [The quire signatures in Hatton 113 , beginning at 'p', are probably a continuation of these.]
supportDesc.condition: The first folios of the manuscript have wormholes, but mostly the condition is very good. There are more holes in parchment towards the end of the book. Fol. 9 has the bottom right (recto) cut away. Fol. 81 has been mended with paper.

layoutDesc.layout: Fols 1–8 : ruled space 198 108 23 lines of two columns for table of contents, with double bounding lines right, left, and centre.
Fols 9–127; 138–45 : ruled space 198 106 23 long lines with double bounding lines, right and left.

Fols 128–137 (Quire 17) : ruled space 187 90
22 long lines with double bounding lines, right and left.

handDesc.handNote: The bulk of the manuscript (fols 5–137) is written by one hand (Ker's Hand 1, Ker 1957, item 338, at p. 417), apparently the same as the main hand of Hatton 113 and Hatton 114 ( Ker 1957, item 331). There are a number of additions (glosses and larger pieces) to the manuscript by at least ten other hands.

Hand 1. Fols 5–137 Ker describes this as a Worcester script; this hand is also found in other Worcester manuscripts including CCCC 178 (1957, p. 417: see also item 41). The 'possible change of hand' on fol. 111 seems to be simply a thicker pen, although ð is slightly different; the overall appearance is similar to Hand 2. same occasional high a
The shape of the second element of æ is influenced by the letter which succeeds it.
e is round-backed or horned depending on its place in the word and the following letter. Wide tail on g .
s is slightly wedgier. The descender of þ is notched. Most ascenders except that of þ are clubbed, but some ascenders have wedged clubs and some are wedged; for example, on h and b , in English and Latin. Some erasures, some additions: found throughout the manuscript. gesƿraecan Added interlinearly. The colour of the added letter a is paler than the main text. It might have been added at a later stage.

Hand 2. Fols 1v-2v This is very like the main hand; in fact, since the first folios are in Latin and much of Hand 1 is written in Old English, the two are not always directly comparable. Where Hand 1 writes in Latin there are similar features: some mixing of clubs and wedges; slant on Caroline h , wedgy p , wide open g . Some letters are distinct enough to suggest that these are two separate hands: more of a wedge on long s has a long descender in this hand.
x has a long descender in this hand.

Hand 3. Fols 148v/10–22; 150r; 150v/16–151r; 152r-3v; 154r/17–154v/12 This hand is angular and upright, the letters are quite narrow, it is possibly the hand of Hemming ( Ker 1948, p. 417). The top of e in æ is very high.
d has a very short and tiny ascender.
g has an open bowl.
h has very tiny feet. Long s is sometimes almost flat-topped. The orum abbreviation slants downwards.
Hand 4. Fols 3–4 This is quite a rounded Caroline script, wedges and clubs are not mixed (unlike in other hands in this manuscript). The orum abbreviation is straight.
Hand 5. Fols 4r-v This hand has long loopy descenders and wedges. Occasionally a big loopy Caroline a .

Hand 6. Fols 138r-48v This is quite like Hand 2, and just possibly could be the same as it, except that this hand seems less practised. This hand is rounder than Hand 1 and sometimes leans to the right slightly. ð tends to flick to the right.

Hand 7. Fols 149r-v; 150v/1–15; 151v This hand has wedges on the feet of minims. ˥ is almost at right-angles. The descenders don't usually have wedges on their feet. On fol 150v/1–15 possibly a thinner pen. y : curves to the left noticeably.
g : has a closed bowl. Long s : very high and has quite a long descender, too. Very wedgy. This is similar to Hands 1 and 2, but quite thick.

Hand 8. Fols 154r/1–16 Uneven hand. The letters are not always firmly on the ruled line. Ascender on d very short long. Has a high e , slightly left-leaning.
a few. Odd ð where the scribe has drawn o and then added an ascender. Closed bowl on g . Long descenders .

Hand 9. Fols 154v-157 This scribe is not good at writing on the lines. This is a left-leaning, flowing script. a : round.
æ : round. Open g . High long s sometimes with descender drooping below the line.
˥ is high. The top of ð curls round to the right. The bottoms of the descenders flick to the left . y long and left-flicking Chunky feet on minims .

Hand 10. Fols 157–60 This hand is quite square and wedgy. d the ascender is short.
y is long and flicks to the left The bowl of g is open.
Hand 11. There are several layers of glosses by the Tremulous Hand in Latin and English. xiii 1

musicNotation.p: Neums, fol. 1r, occasionally elsewhere in the margins.

decoDesc.decoNote: Coloured initials, sometimes with a little decoration. Some blue initials, e.g. fol. 124v; also numerous green and red intials, often used alternately in a text (presumably to highlight sections for reading).

binding.p: Bound, s. xviii , in blind-tooled brown leather (Ure 1957, p. 3)

history.origin:
s. xi 2 (Watson suggests between 1064 and 1083); additions, s. xiii 1
England, Worcester, cathedral priory
history.provenance: Written at Worcester, as evidenced by the script. At Worcester cathedral priory in the thirteenth century, when annotated by the Tremulous Hand. Referred to as a book of 'Worcester Librarye' in 1566 and catalogued at Worcester by Patrick Young in 1622–3 (see Ker). The manuscript was annotated by Joscelyn (fol. 86v, etc.) and perhaps by Archbishop Parker (fol. 4) (Ker).

In the possession of Christopher Lord Hatton in 1644, when used by Dugdale (Bodl. MS. Dugdale 29, fol. iv verso, as cited by Ker). There are notes by Dugdale on fol. iii recto and by Langaine on fols. ii verso, iii recto.
history.acquisition: Passed to Franciscus Junius, 1589–1677 , and acquired after his death by the Bodleian Library in 1678.

recordHist.source: Adapted with minor revisions from the description by Helen Foxhall Forbes with the assistance of Hollie Morgan (September 2010) for The Production and Use of English Manuscripts: 1060 to 1220, reused by permission. Previously described in the Summary Catalogue (1937). Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 2, p. 989 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 2, p. 990

availability.p: To ensure its preservation, access to this item is restricted, and readers are asked to work from reproductions and published descriptions as far as possible. If you wish to apply to see the original, please click the request button above. When your request is received, you will be asked to contact the relevant curator outlining the subject of your research, the importance of this item to that research, and the resources you have already consulted.
